Line 52: Line 52:
===Internet privacy and file sharing===
===Internet privacy and file sharing===
â
[[CNET.com]] gave Biden a 37.5 in its Technology Issues Voter's Guide.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.cnet.com/2009-1040-6130830.html?hhTest=1|title=Technology voter guide 2006 - Mapping Congress' voting records | CNET News.com}}</ref> They referred to Biden as "Pro-RIAA" and "Pro-FBI" in his file sharing and privacy stances. Biden sponsored a bill that would make it a felony to record internet radio,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.cnet.com/Senators-aim-to-restrict-Net,-satellite-radio-recording/2100-1028_3-6149915.html?hhTest=1|title=Senators aim to restrict Net, satellite radio recording - CNET News.com}}</ref> and signed a letter that urged the [[Justice Department]] to prosecute file sharers.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.politechbot.com/docs/congress.p2p.letter.081002.pdf|title=http://www.politechbot.com/docs/congress.p2p.letter.081002.pdf|format=PDF}}</ref> Biden also sponsored two bills, the [http://thomas.loc.gov/cgi-bin/bdquery/z?d102:s.00266: Comprehensive Counter Terrorism Act] and the [http://thomas.loc.gov/cgi-bin/bdquery/z?d102:s.00618: Violent Crime Control Act], both of which contained language effectively banning encryption.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.yahoo.com/s/cnet/20080824/tc_cnet/83011357831002416338 |title=Joe Biden's pro-RIAA, pro-FBI tech voting record - Yahoo! News |accessdate=2008-08-25}}</ref> [[Phil Zimmerman]], creator of PGP, has said it was Biden's legislation (SB 266) that "led me to publish [[Pretty Good Privacy|PGP]] electronically for free that year, shortly before the measure was defeated after vigorous protest by civil libertarians and industry groups."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.philzimmermann.com/EN/essays/index.html |title=Phil Zimmermann on PGP |accessdate=2008-08-25}}</ref>
+
[[CNET.com]] gave Biden a 37.5 in its Technology Issues Voter's Guide.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.cnet.com/2009-1040-6130830.html?hhTest=1|title=Technology voter guide 2006 - Mapping Congress' voting records | CNET News.com}}</ref> They referred to Biden as "Pro-RIAA" and "Pro-FBI" in his file sharing and privacy stances. Biden sponsored a bill that would make it a felony to record internet radio,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.cnet.com/Senators-aim-to-restrict-Net,-satellite-radio-recording/2100-1028_3-6149915.html?hhTest=1|title=Senators aim to restrict Net, satellite radio recording - CNET News.com}}</ref> and signed a letter that urged the [[Justice Department]] to prosecute file sharers.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.politechbot.com/docs/congress.p2p.letter.081002.pdf|title=http://www.politechbot.com/docs/congress.p2p.letter.081002.pdf|format=PDF}}</ref> Biden also sponsored two bills, the [http://thomas.loc.gov/cgi-bin/bdquery/z?d102:s.00266: Comprehensive Counter Terrorism Act] and the [http://thomas.loc.gov/cgi-bin/bdquery/z?d102:s.00618: Violent Crime Control Act], both of which contained language effectively banning encryption.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.yahoo.com/s/cnet/20080824/tc_cnet/83011357831002416338 |title=Joe Biden's pro-RIAA, pro-FBI tech voting record - Yahoo! News |accessdate=2008-08-25}}</ref> [[Phil Zimmerman]], creator of [[Pretty Good Privacy|PGP]], has said it was Biden's legislation (SB 266) that "led me to publish PGP electronically for free that year, shortly before the measure was defeated after vigorous protest by civil libertarians and industry groups."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.philzimmermann.com/EN/essays/index.html |title=Phil Zimmermann on PGP |accessdate=2008-08-25}}</ref>
